The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the World Health Organization (WHO), has classified processed meat as a **Group 1 carcinogen**, meaning it is carcinogenic to humans, and red meat as a **Group 2A carcinogen**, meaning it is probably carcinogenic to humans. These classifications are based on extensive reviews of the scientific literature, including numerous studies that have found consistent associations between high red and processed meat consumption and an increased risk of colorectal cancer.

Processed meats — such as bacon, sausages, hot dogs, and deli meats — often contain preservatives like nitrates and nitrites, which can form cancer-causing compounds in the body. It is important to note that while these associations exist, they do not mean that eating red meat will directly cause cancer. Rather, they indicate that higher consumption is correlated with increased risk, especially when meat is a large part of the diet and other protective dietary factors are lacking.

In summary, the scientific consensus is that **eating large amounts of red and processed meat increases the risk of certain cancers**, particularly colorectal cancer. Moderation, dietary balance, and cooking methods all play a role in minimizing potential risks.
